IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Lead public education to unprecedented levels of academic achievement for all students by fostering a strong charter sector.
IRS990.MissionDesc: The National Alliance for Public Charter Schools is the leading national nonprofit organization committed to advancing the charter school movement. Our mission is to lead public education to unprecedented levels of academic achievement for all students by fostering a strong charter sector.
IRS990.Desc: Federal and State Advocacy: NAPCS works for federal policies that support the growth and stability of high-performing charter schools by educating congressional members, staff and federal agencies about how policy can best support high-quality public charter school growth. In particular, NAPCS seeks to grow the base of support for public charter schools and NAPCS in Washington DC; Maintain or increase federal funding where possible for public charter schools; and protect the autonomy of and ensure fair treatment of public charter schools within federal funding streams, federal regulations, and non-regulatory guidance.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: COMMUNICATIONS & RESEARCH: NAPCS has continued to deliver evidence based information and messages by proactively working with media, and by disseminating its issues briefs, which covers a wide range of IssUes critical to the sector. NAPCS also continues to collect a significant amount of data on the Nation's charter schools. The public charter school dashboard is the most comprehensive source of national data on charter schools, and is consulted regularly by media, researchers, and policy makers.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: National Charter Schools Conference: NAPCS convened the National Charter Schools Conference from June 21-24, 2015. More than 4,700 attendees from across the country gathered in New Orleans, LOUISIANA to learn and promote promising practices, celebrate our successes, and ignite the next level of innovation. The National Charter Schools Conference is NAPCS' primary "Direct to Schools" channel and supports its ability to deepen the evidence base.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: SCHEDULE C SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION PART IV
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The National Alliance for Public Charter Schools is the leading organization committed to advancing quality, growth and sustainability for the movement. We speak and advocate for the hundreds of thousands of other students who are hoping for the chance to attend a charter school. We work at the federal, state and national level to accomplish this purpose. We provide assistance to state charter school associations and resource centers, develop and advocate for improved public policies, and serve as the united voice for this large and diverse movement. We focus on key priorities like replicating and expanding high-quality charter schools, lifting arbitrary "caps" on charter growth and closing the funding gap between charters and other public schools. NAPCS policy experts work directly with federal and state-level organizations to encourage these charter-friendly policies and ultimately ensure charter schools are treated equitably with traditional district public schools under the law.

THE ALLIANCE IS EXEMPT FROM FEDERAL INCOME TAXES UNDER 501(C)(3) OF THE U.S. INTERNAL REVENUE CODE AND ACCORDINGLY, NO PROVISION FOR INCOME TAXES HAS BEEN RECORDED IN THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS. MANAGEMENT HAS EVALUATED THE EFFECT OF THE GUIDANCE PROVIDED BY ACCOUNTING PRINCIPLES GENERALLY ACCEPTED IN THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA. MANAGEMENT BELIEVES THAT THE ALLIANCE CONTINUES TO SATISFY THE REQUIREMENTS OF A TAX-EXEMPT ORGANIZATION AT DECEMBER 31, 2015 AND 2014. MANAGEMENT HAS EVALUATED ALL OTHER TAX POSITIONS THAT COULD HAVE A SIGNIFICANT EFFECT ON THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND DETERMINED THE ALLIANCE HAD NO SIGNIFICANT UNCERTAIN INCOME TAX POSITIONS AT DECEMBER 31, 2015 AND 2014. SHOULD THE TAX-EXEMPT STATUS BE CHALLENGED IN THE FUTURE, THE ALLIANCE'S 2013, 2014, AND 2015 TAX YEARS ARE OPEN FOR EXAMINATION BY THE IRS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 2
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: JED WALLACE, A DIRECTOR, HAS A BUSINESS RELATIONSHIP WITH CHRISTOPHER NELSON, A DIRECTOR.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The State Leaders Council serves as a full voting member of the board. The board term of the chair of the state leaders council will be terminated at the same time as his or her service as chair of the State Leaders Council.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The independent accountant prepares the 990 and sends a draft to NAPCS. The first review is done by the senior director of Finance, chief of staff and the CEO and Presidents. The draft is sent to the finance committee and then to the Board for final approval. The Board reviews the draft, and if the Board communicates no changes, then approves the 990. The senior director of finance communicates that final draft was approved and the independent accountant files the Form with IRS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY IS SIGNED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS BY ALL BOARD MEMBERS. NAPCS IS NOT PERMITTED TO ENGAGE IN ANY PAID PERSONAL CONSULTING arrangements WITH SITTING MEMBERS OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS, WITHOUT AN EXPLICIT BOARD VOTE, WHERE CONFLICTED DIRECTOR RECUSES HIMSELF OR HERSELF. further, THE BOARD MUST APPROVE CONTRACTS WITH ORGANIZATIONS EMPLOYING DIRECTORS, AND THOSE DIRECTORS MUST ABSTAIN FROM ALL discussions and VOTES RELATED TO THOSE CONTRACTS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS DETERMINES THE COMPENSATION LEVEL FOR THE CEO. ALL OTHER EMPLOYEE COMPENSATION IS SET BY THE CEO AND RESEARCHED USING THE COMPENSATION RESOURCES SURVEY FOR NOT-FOR-PROFIT, PIE SALARY SURVEYS, AND FROM SIMILAR ORGANIZATIONS. IN ADDITION, ALL SALARIES ARE ALSO REVIEWED AND APPROVED DURING THE PROCESS OF REVIEW AND APPROVAL OF OUR ANNUAL OPERATING BUDGET PROCESS. ALL DELIBERATIONS ARE DOCUMENTED IN THE MEETING MINUTES.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE ORGANIZATION'S GOVERNING DOCUMENTS, CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY, AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS ARE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC UPON REQUEST.
program consulting fees and other fees: Program service expenses 2,772,946. Management and general expenses 47,414. Fundraising expenses 30,721. Total expenses 2,851,081.
THE ORGANIZATION HAS AN AUDIT COMMITTEE WHICH ASSUMES RESPONSIBILITY FOR OVERSIGHT OF THE AUDIT, FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SELECTION OF THE INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTANT.

IdRelatedTaxExemptOrgGrp.PrimaryActivitiesTxt: SOCIAL WELFARE TO AMPLIFY WORK OF 501(C)(3)
